original_theorem:
If $f^{(n)}(x_0)$ exists$,$ then
\begin{equation}\label{eq:2.5.7}
f(x)=\sum_{r=0}^n\frac{f^{(r)}(x_0)}{ r!} (x-x_0)^r+E_n(x)(x-x_0)^n,
\end{equation}
where
$$
\lim_{x\to x_0} E_n(x)=E_n(x_0)=0.
$$
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem taylor_polynomial_with_remainder {f : ℝ → ℝ} {x₀ : ℝ} {n : ℕ}
    (h_diff_nth : DifferentiableAtN ℝ n f x₀) :
    ∃ (E_n : ℝ → ℝ),
      (∀ x, f x = (∑ r in Finset.range (n + 1), (deriv^[r] f x₀ / (r!) : ℝ) * (x - x₀) ^ r) + E_n x * (x - x₀) ^ n) ∧
      Tendsto E_n (𝓝 x₀) (𝓝 0) ∧ E_n x₀ = 0 := by sorry
```

import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0
open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter
theorem taylor_polynomial_with_remainder {f : ℝ → ℝ} {x₀ : ℝ} {n : ℕ}
    (h_diff_nth : DifferentiableAtN ℝ n f x₀) :
    ∃ (E_n : ℝ → ℝ),
      (∀ x, f x = (∑ r in Finset.range (n + 1), (deriv^[r] f x₀ / (r!) : ℝ) * (x - x₀) ^ r) + E_n x * (x - x₀) ^ n) ∧
      Tendsto E_n (𝓝 x₀) (𝓝 0) ∧ E_n x₀ = 0 := by sorry

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• The n-th derivative of $f$ at $x_0$, $f^{(n)}(x_0)$, exists [tc_1].
• $T_n(x) = \sum_{r=0}^n\frac{f^{(r)}(x_0)}{ r!} (x-x_0)^r$ is the n-th Taylor polynomial of $f$ at $x_0$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• (Implicit premise from (2.5.5)) The limit of the scaled difference between the function and its Taylor polynomial is zero: $\lim_{x\to x_0} \frac{f(x) - T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n} = 0$ [l1].
proof_steps.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure

lean_results.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure
lean_results.error_msg: Skipped due to previous verification failure

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• $E_n(x)$ is defined as $E_n(x) = \frac{f(x)-T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n}$ for $x \neq x_0$ and $E_n(x_0)=0$ [def_1].
• $\lim_{x\to x_0} \frac{f(x) - T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n} = 0$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The limit of $E_n(x)$ as $x$ approaches $x_0$ is equal to its value at $x_0$, and both are zero: $\lim_{x\to x_0} E_n(x) = E_n(x_0) = 0$ [ts_1].
proof_steps.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• $T_n(x) = \sum_{r=0}^n\frac{f^{(r)}(x_0)}{ r!} (x-x_0)^r$ and $E_n(x)$ is defined piece-wise as $E_n(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{f(x)-T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n} & \text{if } x \neq x_0 \\ 0 & \text{if } x = x_0 \end{cases}$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For all $x \in D_f$, $f(x) = \sum_{r=0}^n\frac{f^{(r)}(x_0)}{ r!} (x-x_0)^r+E_n(x)(x-x_0)^n$ [ts_2].

  sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure
  sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure
  sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure
